Environmental Significance Statement
Graphene-based nanomaterials are versatile functional materials for environmental applications such as adsorption, catalysis. However, recovery of the used nanomaterials from the environment is always a tough task and the recovery rate is usually low. The unrecovered nanomaterials will be transferred and transformed in the environment, resulting serious environmental impacts, e.g., toxicity to organisms. Graphene-containing membranes (GCMs) constructed from or modified by graphene and its derivatives may relief the environmental impacts of graphene-based nanomaterials because GCM is macroscopic (easy recovery) and the stability of the incorporated nanomaterials can be further adjusted. More importantly, the function and performance of membrane may be soundly enhanced by the incorporated graphene-based nanomaterials, resulting some unique applications (besides conventional membrane functions) and generally higher sustainability of GCMs.

Abstract 22
Graphene based nanomaterials are versatile functional materials with extraordinary properties. 23
Graphene-containing membranes (GCMs) are advanced separation devices constructed from or modified 24
by graphene and its derivatives, which not only presented attractive functions and performances but also 25
generated less residual nanomaterials afterwards, and thus, lower impacts to the environment than 26
directly using graphene based nanomaterials. Since GCMs have demonstrated significant sustainability 27
in various applications, they have attracted tremendous attention from both academia and industry. To 28
summarize the state-of-the-art works and guide the future development of GCMs, a full survey of the 29
theoretical and experimental approaches using graphene based nanomaterials to construct new 30
membranes and modify existing membranes was provided in this review. GCMs were divided into 31
monolayer porous graphene membranes (SGM), multilayer pristine graphene-containing membranes 32
(MGM), multilayer composite graphene-containing membranes (CGM), and conventional membranes 33
modified with graphene based materials (PGM). Subsequently, the applications of GCMs in isotope 34
separation, gas separation, desalination, ion separation, nanofiltration, ultrafiltration, and pervaporation 35
were summarized. Multifunctional GCMs with conductive, antifouling, adsorptive, and photoactive 36
properties were also illustrated. The environmental impacts of graphene based nanomaterials and the 37
safe-by-design concept for GCMs were subsequently discussed. The mechanisms behind the GCM 38
construction and the GCM performance/function were highlighted. In addition to the advantages of 39
graphene contained membranes over conventional membranes, the challenges during GCM fabrication 40
and their limitations were analysed to envision the development of next-generation graphene-containing 41
membranes. 42

1. Introduction 55
Graphene is a single layered atomically thin two-dimensional nanomaterial of sp2 hybridized carbon 56 atoms arranged in a honeycomb lattice.1 Owing to the unique lattice structure, graphene possesses 57 extraordinary mechanical strength,2 thermal conductivity3 and electrical conductivity,4 which makes 58 graphene an attractive functional material.5 Moreover, a broad range of graphene derivatives have been 59
developed to further extend the capability of graphene based materials. Graphene oxide (GO) is one of 60
the most important graphene derivatives, which preserves most of the properties of graphene but is water 61
dispersible due to the hydrophilic and reactive oxygen-containing functional groups such as hydroxyl, 62 carbonyl, carboxylic, and epoxy groups.6 The amount of oxygen-containing functional groups in GO can 63
be adjusted easily during preparation, which is essential for subsequent modification of the graphene 64 derivative.7 In particular, functionalization refers to the covalently bonding of specific functional groups 65
onto the graphene sheet, whereas doping is the incorporation of heteroatoms into the graphene carbon 66 lattice. For example, GO was sulfonated by sulfuric acid,8 nitrogen was doped into the graphene to 67 replace some carbon atoms.9 Both functionalization and doping may further modulate the properties of 68
graphene for a wider range of applications in high performance. 69
Notably, graphene based nanomaterials were directly applied in the environmental field such as 70
adsorbents in water and wastewater treatment for heavy metal ion and organic compound adsorption, 71 catalysts for degradation of organic compounds, reduction of heavy metals, and water disinfection.10 In 72
these cases, considerable amount of graphene based nanomaterials would be released into the 73
environment during application since graphene and its derivatives are usually small sheets (from 74 nanometer to micrometer scale);11 and thus, difficult to be recycled. Potentially, the huge amount of 75 released graphene based nanomaterials may cause adverse environmental impacts.12 76

To preserve the extraordinary properties of graphene based nanomaterials but further extend the 77
application of them in more practical and broader fields, macroscopic and recyclable graphene-78 containing structures such as 1D fiber,13 2D film14 and 3D macrostructure15, 16 were developed, which 79
may also reduce the environmental release of graphene based nanomaterials. For example, graphene was 80
spun into fibers with an extremely high mechanical strength, flexibility and conductivity for different 81 applications such as electrical conductors, supercapacitors, actuators and solar cells.13 In addition, low 82
density carbon aerogels were prepared by assembling giant graphene sheets with enhanced stability 83 attributed to the added carbon nanotubes.17 Graphene based 3D macroscopic aerogels exhibited high 84
capabilities for the removal of pollutants, such as dye (methylene blue) and heavy metals (Cd2+) from 85 water.15, 16 Nevertheless, the pore sieving function was missing from the above mentioned 86
macrostructures. Membrane which is an advanced separation device is another promising sustainable 87
application of graphene based nanomaterials. 88
Various functional membranes could be prepared, benefitting from the excellent properties of 89
graphene and its derivative. The monolayer graphene sheet is an ideal material for membrane because of 90 its atomic thickness, frictionless surface, as well as mechanical and chemical stability.18 However, the 91
one-atom-thin graphene crystal is impermeable even to the smallest molecules such as hydrogen and 92 helium.19 To achieve the separation purpose, pores drilled on the graphene sheet were studied through 93 theoretical simulations.20-22 Subsequently, physical pores were drilled on the monolayer graphene 94 sheet.23, 24 Although the atomically thin and porous graphene sheet is perfect as a membrane, the main 95
challenges of the practical application of pristine graphene are the fabrication of large-area monolayer 96 graphene sheets and the scaling-up of the production process.25 97
On the other hand, as the most important and commonly used graphene derivative, GO has a better 98
affinity to water. Thus, GO nanosheets can be well dispersed in water and subsequently assembled into 99

laminated structures with interconnected interlayer spaces, which are perfect channels for the rapid 100 permeation of water molecules but retain the other molecules and some ions.26 In addition to the porous 101
monolayer graphene membrane, assembled graphene derivative sheets in laminated form represent the 102
second primary type of graphene based membranes. In addition, the size of the interlayer channels can 103 be further adjusted to fast-sieve ions and molecules from aqueous solutions.27 Gas separation was also 104 achieved using the assembled GO laminates.28-30 105
Owing to the special properties of graphene and its derivatives, functions in addition to separation 106
could be introduced to the graphene-containing membranes for extended applications. For example, 107 graphene is electrically conductive,4 which results in conductive graphene-containing membranes. 108
Membrane surface properties, such as hydrophilicity and surface charge, can be tuned by assembling 109 functionalized graphene derivatives on the membrane surface to prevent membrane fouling.31 Graphene 110 and its derivatives are excellent absorbents of organic pollutants.32 Thus, multifunctional membranes 111
with both separation and adsorption functions can be constructed from graphene based nanomaterials. 112
Since the first piece of graphene sheet was peeled from graphite, there have been a number of studies 113
focused on the development of graphene-containing membrane (GCM). Some reviews have partly 114
summarized the research works of graphene based membrane. For example, Liu classified the graphene 115
based membrane fabrication approaches into three forms: a porous graphene layer, assembled graphene 116
laminates and graphene based composites; applications including pressure filtration, pervaporation and 117 gas separation were summarized.25 However, membrane surface modification studies using graphene 118
were not included; furthermore, the unique application of GCM such as isotopic separation and ion 119
separation were also not included. In another review, the main focus was put on understanding mass 120 transport through graphene based membranes rather than membrane construction and application.33 121
Some reviews either only partly included the materials and approaches for graphene based membrane 122

construction34-36 or only partly summarized the applications of graphene based membrane.37, 38 On the 123
other hand, some reviews discussed broader topics such as membranes fabricated from carbon 124 nanomaterials39 or 2D nanomaterials40, 41 and environmental application of graphene based 125 nanomaterials,10 which selectively summarized the graphene-containing membrane studies in a 126
subsection. Nevertheless, as one of the most popular research topics, studies on the advanced fabrication 127
and application of GCMs, such as the precise interlayer tuning of laminated GCM and the separation of 128
isotopes is progressing rapidly over the last few years. Thus, a well-organized and more comprehensive 129
review of state-of-art graphene-containing membrane is urgently needed. 130
In this review, we intend to provide a full survey of the methods to fabricate membrane from 131
graphene and its derivatives as well as the approaches for modifying membranes using graphene based 132
materials. Subsequently, we will focus on the applications of GCM. The mechanisms that drive the high 133
performance of GCM will be highlighted. Moreover, the advantages and limitations of GCMs will be 134
discussed. Finally, we will propose a few perspectives on the future development of GCMs for practical 135
applications. 136
137
2. Graphene-Containing Membranes and Fabrication Approaches 138
The graphene-containing membranes (GCMs) discussed in this review will cover pristine 139
membranes constructed from grapheme based nanomaterials alone, composite membranes containing 140
other components besides grapheme based nanomaterials and surface-modified membranes using 141
grapheme based nanomaterials, as shown in Figure 1. In the first group of GCMs, both single-layer 142
graphene sheet with pores (SGM) and laminated graphene multilayers with interlayer spaces as 143
nanochannels (MGM) can sieve molecules. Second, graphene and its derivatives will be combined with 144
the other compounds to fabricate multilayer composite membranes (CGM). In the third group, the 145

Figure 1. Schematic illustration of graphene-containing membranes (GCMs). (a) Monolayer porous 150 graphene membrane (SGM), (b) multilayer pristine graphene-containing membranes (MGM), (c) 151 multilayer composite graphene-containing membranes (CGM) and (d) membranes modified with 152 grapheme based materials (PGM). 153 154 2.1 Monolayer Porous Graphene Membrane (SGM). A perfect pristine graphene sheet is 155
impermeable, which was verified using different gases through a micro-chamber capped with a graphene 156
sheet; it was reported that even the smallest gas molecule (helium) could not penetrate the graphene 157 sheet fabricated by mechanical exfoliation.42 The theoretical calculated geometric pore size of the 158
graphene sheet is 0.064 nm, which is smaller than the diameters of helium (0.28 nm) and hydrogen 159 (0.314 nm).19 However, Geim’s group recently found that hydrogen ions (thermal protons) may 160 penetrate a defect-free graphene sheet,43 which had been used to separate hydrogen ion isotopes.44 To 161
extend the application of monolayer graphene membranes, larger pores must be drilled on the graphene 162
sheets to enable the penetration of molecules larger than protons. On one hand, the formation of porous 163
monolayer graphene membranes (SGMs) for different applications has typically been studied using 164
theoretical simulations. On the other hand, the experimental fabrication of porous SGMs was achieved 165

9
using high-energy irradiation, such as UV and plasma, to drill pores on monolayer graphene sheets 166
produced by mechanical exfoliation and chemical vapor deposition. 167 The first piece of monolayer graphene sheet was produced by mechanical exfoliation1 which is the 168
most commonly used approach for fabricating perfect or nonporous monolayer graphene sheets for 169
different applications. The exfoliated monolayer graphene sheet is an excellent membrane substrate 170 because of its one-atom thickness and the extraordinary mechanical property of the graphene sheets.45 171
Thus, various methods had been used to drill holes on monolayer graphene sheets to fabricate SGMs. 172
For example, UV-induced oxidative etching was used to generate 0.34 nm and 0.49 nm pores in 5 µm 173 graphene sheets.23 However, the size of a single piece of a graphene flake produced by mechanical 174 exfoliation is limited to the micrometre range,46 which limits the practically application of SGMs 175
fabricated through mechanical exfoliation. 176
Chemical vapour deposition (CVD) is another emergent powerful technique for fabricating 177
monolayer graphene films. In a typical CVD process, a mixture of methane and hydrogen is heated to 178 1000 °C in a chamber, while the monolayer graphene film grows on a copper foil.47 The pyrolysis of 179
methane under reduction conditions will generate dissociated carbon atoms, which will subsequently 180 reorganize and form covalently linked 2D carbon networks or graphene.48 Once the monolayer graphene 181
film is formed by CVD, the film can be transferred to a porous supporting substrate, and molecules can 182
be sieved by the film defects or the pores drilled during post-treatments. For example, a monolayer CVD 183 graphene film (area: 25 mm2) was transferred to a porous polycarbonate substrate by a simple pressing 184
procedure, and the intrinsic defects of the film were used for selective molecular transport, which was 185 driven by pressure and diffusion.49, 50 Similarly, intrinsic CVD graphene films were transferred directly 186
onto different flexible substrates such as polycarbonate, a polytetrafluoroethylene filter, polyvinyl 187 chloride, and a cellulose nitrate/cellulose acetate filter via lamination.51 188

To modify the selectivity and permeability of the pristine monolayer CVD graphene films, artificial 189 pores were generated by post-treatments to fabricate SGMs. For example, high density (1012 cm−2) pores 190
with diameters of 0.40 ± 0.24 nm were produced in a CVD graphene film by introducing reactive 191 defects through ion bombardment and subsequent oxidative etching.52 Nanopores ranging from <10 nm 192
to 1 µm were drilled with a focused ion beam (FIB) in a free-standing graphene film fabricated by CVD 193 to produce super-thin graphene membranes (thickness < 1 nm).53 A controlled oxygen plasma etching 194 process was applied to create nanopores (0.5-1 nm) in a single-layer CVD graphene film.24 195
Currently, CVD is the most commonly used approach to generate large-area single piece monolayer 196 graphene sheets, which may be as large as several inches.54, 55 However, the relatively “large area” is 197
still significantly smaller than the area required for practical membrane filtration. As a substrate-based 198
approach, bottleneck of the CVD technology is very difficult to be scaled up. In addition, most of the 199
pore-drilling approaches for SGM production are unable to precisely control the pore size and 200
distribution. Although SGMs are the ideal membranes with an atomic thickness that results in 201
extraordinary permeability, the current fabrication technologies are still unable to produce SGMs for 202
practical applications. In the future, more efforts should be put in the development of technology which 203
is able to fabricate large area single layer grapheme as well as technology which is able to generate well 204
distributed pores with precise size control. 205
206
2.2 Multilayer Pristine Graphene-Containing Membrane (MGM). GO can be easily prepared 207
by exfoliation of graphite through oxidation, which functionalizes the basal planes with oxygen 208
containing groups and increases the interlayer spacing of graphite. GO can also be reduced to produce 209 reduced graphene oxide (rGO). The Hummers’ method is commonly used to oxidize graphite to GO,56 210 and various reduction approaches have been applied to fabricate rGO.57, 58 Besides chemical exfoliation 211

protocols, the improved mechanical exfoliation techniques are also able to produce large quantity of 212 graphene micro/nano-sheets46 which can be further functionalized into graphene derivatives such as GO. 213
However, the sizes of graphene and its derivatives are usually in micrometer scale which is much 214
smaller than the size of a regular membrane for filtration. Thus, the methods of transforming graphene 215
or GO nano/micro sheets into large-area membranes are crucial for the introduction of the ultimate 216
properties of grapheme based materials into membranes. In general, these approaches can reorganize 217
graphene derivative sheets into ordered multilayers. Due to the interactions among the assembled 218
graphene derivative sheets, multilayer graphene-containing membranes (MGMs) will be formed with 219
nano-sized interlayer spaces which are responsible for molecular sieving. In this section, only MGMs 220
with one component will be discussed. The methods of fabricating MGMs such as filtration, interfacial 221
assembly, coating and casting will be summarized in this section. 222

Vacuum/Pressure-Assisted Filtration for the Fabrication of MGMs. Filtration is a commonly used 231
method to fabricate MGMs, as shown in Figure 2a. To form well-ordered graphene derivative sheets in 232
MGMs, the solute must be homogeneously distributed in the filtrate before filtration. Since the graphene 233
sheet is highly hydrophobic and will aggregate in water because of the π-π interactions between 234
nanosheets, it is very difficult to homogeneously distribute pure graphene sheets in water compared to 235
non-polar solvents. By contrast, the graphene oxide (GO) sheet consists of abundant hydrophilic and 236
negatively charged oxygen functional groups on its basal plane and edges, which can easily form 237
homogeneous aqueous dispersions because the abundant hydrophilic oxygen containing functional 238
groups of GO may increase the solubility of GO in water, and the electrostatic repulsion among 239 negatively charged GO sheets may reduce the aggregation.61 Thus, GO was more frequently used to 240 fabricate oriented layered MGMs via filtration in aqueous systems.62 The GO sheets and the formed GO 241
MGMs can easily be further modified to meet different application requirements. 242
Vacuum filtration generated a directional flow, which drove the assembly of colloidal graphene 243
oxide sheets in aqueous dispersions to form well-ordered macroscopic structures; after drying and 244
peeling, a free-standing GO MGM was fabricated with a thickness ranging from 1 to 10 µm, which 245 indicates the presence of well-packed multilayers in the cross-section.63 Similarly, well-dispersed stable 246
aqueous synthetic GO colloids were vacuum filtrated to form paper-like MGMs on alumina supporting 247 membranes,61, 64 ceramic hollow fibers65 and PTFE filters.66 GO nanosheets were also reduced by 248
hydrazine to rGO nanosheets, which contained less oxygen functional groups and less surface defects; 249
rGO aqueous suspensions were also vacuum filtrated to form macroscopic, free-standing, robust, and 250 flexible MGMs.67, 68 In addition, highly hydrophilic or underwater oleophobic GO membranes were 251 assembled from UV-irradiated GO sheets via a vacuum filtration method.69 A pressurized ultrafiltration 252
method was also used to assemble GO MGMs with thickness values of 2 and 10 µm on a polycarbonate 253

supporting membrane, resulting in well-packed GO sheets and good mechanical strength of the formed 254 MGMs.70 Similarly, GO MGMs (thickness < 1 µm) were prepared on modified polyacrylonitrile 255 substrates via pressure-assisted filtration.59 The membrane thickness, which is related to the performance, 256
can be adjusted by modifying the volume and concentration of the GO suspension during filtration. The 257
thickness of the rGO MGM assembled by vacuum filtration on an anodic aluminum oxide (AAO) 258 supporting membrane could be as thin as approximately 22-53 nm.71 By diluting the GO dispersion for 259 vacuum filtration, the thickness of the MGM could be further reduced to approximately 1.8 nm.29 260
More importantly, the interlayer spacing or nanochannel of the MGM, which determines the 261
membrane selectively and permeability, can be modulated through different approaches. The average 262 interlayer spacing between planes of graphite or pristine graphene is ~0.34 nm.72 Normally, the 263
nanochannels of MGMs created by restacking exfoliated GO sheets via vacuum filtration assembly are 264 ~1 nm.73 To further expand the interlayer space of MGM, either defects or wrinkles were purposely 265
created on the layered materials or removable spacers were inserted into the layers during assembly. For 266
example, the MGM membranes fabricated from the rGO treated at a higher temperature (larger 267 corrugation) indicated the presence of larger nanochannels.74 The temperature-dependent decomposition 268
reaction of ammonium nitrate was also used to tune the interlayer spacing of a pristine GO MGM for a 269
designed permeability; a large range of the spacing from 123% to 20000% could be achieved without 270 the existence of guest molecules as spacers.75 A higher pressure would produce a more compact MGM 271
with collapsed nanochannels. However, the channel collapse was reversible because of the elasticity of 272
the GO sheets. The interlayer space of the MGM would shrink with decreasing pH and increasing ionic 273 strength, while the electrostatic repulsions among the negatively charged GO sheets decrease.76 To 274
further increase the permeability of MGMs, GO sheets were re-oxidized to form in-plane pores, which 275 act as shortcuts in the interlayer nanochannels.77 276

The filtration approaches to fabricate MGMs are easy to apply and scale up. More important, they 277
are able to reorganize graphene derivative sheets in a well-ordered manner. The main limitation of the 278
filtration and assembly approach is the need for a supporting membrane as the substrate, which increases 279
the difficulty of fabricating free-standing graphene derivative MGMs. Although a recent study indicated 280
that unintentionally introduced multivalent cationic metal contaminants may improve the stability of 281 MGMs in water,78 the stability of MGMs remains a primary concern. 282
Coating and Casting for the Fabrication of MGMs. Coating and casting are very straightforward 283
methods to fabricate MGMs. Graphene derivative dispersions will be directly deposited on the substrate 284
surface to form MGMs. The thickness of the MGM was mainly determined by the concentration of the 285
graphene derivative dispersion during dip coating. However, in addition to the dispersion concentration, 286
factors such as the applied dispersion volume during spray coating and drop casting, the spinning speed 287
during spin coating and the blade gap during blade casting may be adjusted to prepare MGMs with 288
controlled thicknesses. 289
Free-standing MGMs were fabricated by drop casting GO aqueous dispersions on a smooth paper 290 followed by drying and detaching. 50, 79-81 GO dispersions were spin or spray coated on copper foils; 291
after drying, the copper foils were removed by etching to leave the free-standing GO MGMs with a 292 thickness from 0.1 to 10 µm, as shown in Figure 2c and d.26 293
GO dispersions were also spin coated on porous supporting membranes to form MGMs with 294 thicknesses in the hundreds of nanometers82 and a few nanometers.83 In addition, the supporting 295 substrates were pretreated to improve the stability of dip-coated MGMs on top. 84, 85 GO MGMs (3 to 10 296 nm) were prepared by directly spin coating the GO dispersions on a supporting membrane repeatedly.28 297
As shown in Figure 2b, a doctor blade with an adjustable gap between the blade and the substrate was 298 used to cast GO dispersions on a Nylon supporting membrane.60 299

Since the coating and casting approaches are well developed and highly scalable, these methods may 300
be used to fabricate large-area MGMs. However, the interspaces between the assembled sheets, which 301
act as the nanochannels for molecular separation, are difficultly adjusted using the coating and casting 302
methods to prepare pristine MGMs. 303
Interface Assembly for the Fabrication of MGMs. Graphene based nanosheets would accumulate at 304
the interface of two different phases (i.e., air/liquid phases, first liquid/second liquid phases) because the 305 flakes prefer to create a new interface to minimize the interface energy.86 These phenomena were used 306
to assemble monolayer and multilayer graphene derivative films. However, the monolayer film formed 307
via interface assembly approaches is composed of loosely packed graphene derivative sheets, which is 308
different from the one-piece monolayer graphene derivative films (SGM). 309
Langmuir - Blodgett (LB) assembly is one of the commonly used interface assembly approaches. In 310
a typical LB assembly, amphiphilic molecules will be dispersed in a volatile organic solvent and 311
homogeneously spread on a water surface. Once the organic solvent is evaporated, a monolayer of the 312
molecules will float on the water surface, whose area or the distance between molecules can be adjusted 313
by a moving barrier. During compression, the molecules can collapse from a monolayer into multilayers. 314 The monolayer or multilayers can subsequently be transferred to a substrate with a particular area.87 315
GO sheets were dispersed in a water/methanol (1:5) mixture and spread on a water surface. After 316
compression, monolayer GO films were repeatedly transferred to a substrate to form multilayer GO 317 films.87 Dichloroethane was also used to disperse graphene sheets, which were assembled into MGMs 318 via the LB method.88 On the other hand, GO sheets may also self-assemble at the liquid/air interface. 319
Free-standing GO MGMs were fabricated with controllable thickness and area by evaporating aqueous 320 dispersions of GO sheets.89 Nevertheless, the interface assembly approaches are usually time consuming, 321

MGMs fabricated by these approaches is another concern. 323
Layer-by-Layer Assembly for the Fabrication of MGMs. Layer by layer (LbL) assembly is a 324
versatile multilayer film preparation approach, which is able to precisely control the quantity and type of 325
the components in each layer of the film. In general, LbL assembly is driven by electrostatic attraction. 326
Two components bearing opposite charges are alternately assembled on a substrate to form multilayers. 327
Thus, a graphene derivative can be modified with opposite charges and subsequently alternately 328 assembled on a charged substrate to form MGMs with controllable properties, such as thickness.90 329
However, due to the intrinsic negative charges of GO, its cooperation with a positively charged 330
component to form composite graphene-containing membranes is more frequently applied using LbL 331
assembly, which will be discussed later. 332
The ideal MGM membranes should preserve the permeability and selectivity of SGMs but should be 333
much easier to scale up for practical applications. However, the performance optimization or further 334
functionalization of MGMs is difficult because only very limited parameters can be adjusted to a limited 335
extent. Furthermore, membrane stability is another main concern of MGM because of the weak 336
interactions between graphene based nanosheets. 337

2.3 Multilayer Composite Graphene-Containing Membrane (CGM). Although grapheme based 339
nanomaterials possess extraordinary properties, pristine MGMs also have certain limitations. To 340
overcome these limitations and improve the properties of graphene-containing membranes, functional 341
components in addition to grapheme based materials were introduced to the membranes, forming 342
multilayer composite graphene-containing membranes (CGMs). Most of the approaches used to 343
fabricate multilayer pristine graphene-containing membranes (MGMs) are also applicable to CGMs. 344
Thus, the purpose of including additional functional components will be discussed in this section. 345

Channel Size Tuning by the Additional Component of CGMs. Since CGMs are formed with 346
laminated structures, the interlayer space or channel is the sieving barrier during filtration. The 347
additional component of CGMs may be used to adjust the size of interlayer channel over a wide range to 348
obtain substances with different sizes. 349
GO-TiO2 composite sheets were prepared and subsequently assembled into CGMs via vacuum 350
filtration. The existence of TiO2 would enlarge the interlayer distance between the assembled nanosheets 351 and enhance the adsorption capacities of the formed CGM membranes.91 Positively charged copper 352
hydroxide nanostrands (CHNs) were blended with negatively charged GO sheets to prepare a mixed 353
dispersion, which was filtered to form multilayer films. After removing the CHNs, the fabricated CGM 354
membrane exhibited an obviously enhanced permeability without sacrificing its rejection rate in the UF 355 range, as observed in Figure 3a.92 Three diamines with different lengths were used to crosslink GO 356
sheets, and they functioned as spacers to adjust the interspace between the GO sheets in the range from 357 10.4 to 8.7 Å after self-assembly via pressure-assisted filtration to form CGMs, as shown in Figure 3b.93 358 LbL assembly is a versatile tool to construct CGMs with precisely designed interlayer channel size,27 as 359
shown in Figure 3c. 360
Stability Enhancement by the Additional Component of CGMs. In general, membranes need to 361
sustain the transmembrane pressure and special conditions, such as a high ionic strength and high 362
temperature environment, during filtrations. Thus, stability is one of the most important properties of 363
membrane. The interaction among the MGM membrane layers is mainly the π-π attraction which is not 364
strong enough for binding the layers in practical applications. To improve the membrane stability, 365
additional functional materials were used to construct more stable CGMs. 366

functions were also introduced to the CGM membranes by the additional components. For example, to 406
enhance the affinity of graphene sheets to water, amphiphilic 1-pyrenebutyrate was non-covalently 407
combined with graphene sheets to generate a stable aqueous dispersion, which was subsequently filtered 408 to fabricate large-area flexible CGMs.106 GO sheets were functionalized with sulfonated propylsilane 409
and mixed with sulfonated polyimide in DMAc to form a homogeneous mixture, which was casted and 410 evaporated to form CGMs with enhanced water-retention properties and proton conduction.107 411

to form composites, which were dip coated on ceramic supporting membranes to form a multifunctional 413

cleaning function were endowed to the CGM membrane, which was constructed by filtering TiO2 416 spheres and an aqueous mixture of sulfonated graphene oxide nanosheets.109 A thermal-responsive CGM 417
membrane was fabricated from GO sheets grafted with a thermally responsive molecule-418
poly(sulfobetaine). Consequently, the specific storage capacity of the CGM membrane for Li was 419 reversibly decreased by >50% when it was heated from 20 to 80°C.110 420

precisely control interlayer spacing. Ideally inserting molecules with certain size into the layers as 427

2.4 Surface Modified Membrane Using Graphene Based Nanomaterials (PGM). In addition to 432
being used as the building blocks to directly construct barriers, graphene and its derivatives were also 433
used to modify the properties and improve the performance of membranes without affecting the pore 434
structure or sieving effect of the original membrane. These membranes will be denoted as PGMs, and 435
the modification approaches will be summarized in this section. 436
Coatings are the simplest surface modification approach. For example, stainless-steel grids were 437
repeatedly dip coated with rGO dispersed in DMF to generate a super-wetting surface, which was able 438 to adsorb organic compounds or oils from water.111 GO was mixed with chitosan and subsequently 439
coated onto a polyamide composite RO membrane to increase the hydrophilicity and decrease the 440 roughness.112 A polysulfone UF membrane was sequentially immersed in TiO2 and GO suspensions 441 followed by UV curing to form a photocatalytic and hydrophilic PGM.113 GO nanosheets were 442
decorated with silver nanoparticles, which were coordinated with thiol groups grafted on a polyamide 443 composite membrane via dip coating; this resulted in a stable hydrophilic and antimicrobial PGM.114 444
LbL assembly is a versatile surface modification method to precisely tune the properties of 445
membranes. For example, GO sheets were reacted with ethylenediamine to generate positive charges 446
and subsequently deposited with pristine GO via LbL assembly on a polyamide membrane surface to 447 improve the stability, hydrophilicity and smoothness without scarifying the membrane permeability.115 448
In addition, various grapheme based nanomaterials were dispersed on cellulose nitrate membrane filter 449 surfaces via vacuum filtration to endow the membrane with an antibacterial property.116 450

Surface grafting is a commonly used surface modification approach, which may form stable 451
functional layers on the target membrane surface. GO nanosheets were covalently bonded to a modified 452 polyethersulfone (PES) UF membrane to improve the hydrophilicity and water flux.117 GO nanosheets, 453
gold nanostars and polyethylene glycol were covalently grafted onto a polyamide RO membrane surface 454 to increase the hydrophilicity and decrease the roughness.118 455
Phase inversion is the most commonly used approach to prepare polymeric membranes. GO was 456
used as an additive to enhance the membrane surface hydrophilicity. For example, GO was added into 457
the polysulfone NMP solution, which was subsequently solidified by phase inversion to form CGMs 458 with improved hydrophilicity.119 GO and poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (pore forming) were used as additives 459
in asymmetric poly(vinylylidenefluoride) (PVDF) composite UF membranes formed via phase inversion 460 to improve hydrophilicity.120 461
Ideally, surface modification approaches may bring the desired surface properties of grapheme based 462
nanomaterials, such as hydrophilicity and an antibacterial effect, to the target membrane surface without 463
affecting the original selectivity of the modified PGMs. However, most of the surface modification 464
studies emphasized the mitigation of membrane fouling, while understating the other valuable functions 465
of grapheme based materials. Presumably, more effort should be focused on transferring the properties 466
from grapheme based materials to the membrane surface through surface modification. 467

achieve gas separation, the sieving barriers were developed in two major ways including drilling of 494

Pores can be generated on the graphene lattice by removing a certain number of carbon atoms. For 497
example, MD simulations were carried out to remove 11 to 32 carbon atoms from the graphene lattice to 498
form pores ranging from 3.7 Å to 8.6 Å; specifically, the small pore missing 11 carbon atoms was able 499 to separate H2 from N2. 125 The 9.9 Å diameter pores were drilled on the graphene sheet to separate CO2 500 from CO2/O2, CO2/N2 and CO2/CH4 mixtures. 126 In another MD simulation, the penetration of CO2 501 through a 3.1 Å pore on the graphene sheet was 35 times larger than that of CH4. 127 Experimentally, 502
pores were drilled in bilayer graphene membranes by ultraviolet-induced oxidative etching in the 503 subnanometer range to separate H2 from air molecules (mostly N2 and O2). 23 Similarly, the physically 504
perforated double-layer graphene sheet with pores less than 10 nm exhibited an approximately 5 times 505 higher H2 selective permeability over CO2. 53 506
On the other hand, unsaturated carbon atoms on the edge of the drilled pore can be either passivated 507
with hydrogen atoms or replaced by other atoms such as nitrogen to further adjust the pore size in theory. 508

3.6 Pervaporation. Pervaporation is an effective approach for solvent dehydration, which may 673
remove a trace amount of water from solvent/water azeotropes. The membrane used for pervaporation 674
must have a high affinity for water, and it may selectively adsorb water molecules and subsequently 675
allow water molecules to pass through while other solvent molecules are retained. The liquid-phase 676
permeate will be evaporated and rapidly removed. Hydrophilic multilayer GCMs are excellent 677
candidates for pervaporation. On one hand, the membrane hydrophilicity may enhance the water 678
adsorption. More importantly, the rapid water channel of multilayer GCMs ensures fast transmembrane 679 transport of water molecules.26 680 Porous inorganic materials such as ceramics65, 85 and aluminum oxide99 were used as supports for 681
GO sheets to construct pervaporation membranes. In addition, laminated GCMs were also assembled on 682 porous polymeric supports, such as polyacrylonitrile,59 polycarbonate,70 polyacrylonitrile101 and 683 composite polymeric supports.82, 93, 94 Nevertheless, free-standing CGMs composed of GO and sodium 684 alginate102 or chitosan104 were applied for dehydration through pervaporation processes. 685

4. Safe-by-Design Concept for GCMs 734
Besides the attractive properties of graphene based nanomaterials in various applications, their 735
environmental behaviors and impacts are also drawing attention. 736
Graphene based nanomaterials may go through processes such as adsorption, dispersion and 737
aggregation in the aquatic environment. Owing to the electrostatic repulsion contributed by the abundant 738
carboxyl groups of GO, the GO nanosheets tended to be dispersed in water while graphene and rGO 739 would easily aggregate because of the carboxyl group elimination.61 Generally, the environmental 740
behavior of graphene based nanomaterials could be affected by the chemical and physical conditions 741
such as pH value, ionic strength, as well as presence of ions, NOM, colloids and particles of the 742 solution.12, 151 For example, the presence of cations especially heavy metal cations in the solution may 743 destabilize the GO nanosheets, resulting aggregation to different extents.152 However, it was found that 744
in most natural aquatic environments such as surface water, groundwater, and wastewater the GO 745 nanosheets were stable and may transport in water significantly.12, 153 In addition, obvious 746
biodegradation of graphene based nanomaterials in the natural aquatic environment has not been 747 observed and evidenced yet.12 748
The toxicity of graphene based nanomaterials had been studied both in vitro and in vivo for animals, 749
cells and bacteria; the available results indicated that graphene based nanomaterials were not devoid of 750 possible risks to human health or the environment.154 Two main possible mechanisms for the toxicity of 751
graphene nanomaterials were proposed: firstly, atomically thin graphene based nanosheets might cut 752 open and physically damage cell membranes, resulting cell death;12, 154, 155 secondly, intracellular 753
oxidative stress induced by graphene based nanomaterials is another widely accepted mechanism for 754 cytotoxicity.12, 154, 155 In addition, the toxicity of graphene or rGO was compared with its derivative – 755
GO, but opposite conclusions were drawn in different studies. In some studies, the rGO nanosheet was 756

Nevertheless, higher stability and more significant transportation of GO in the aquatic environment 761
should cause more serious environmental impacts in terms of longer toxic effect and larger affected 762

On the initial stage of applying the emerging graphene based nanomaterials for environmental 764
remediation as adsorbent or catalysis, the effect and performance of the functional nanomaterial are 765
always the main concerns. Thus, graphene and its derivative in nano-sized shapes were usually directly 766
dosed into the aquatic environment for pollutants such as heavy metal ions and organic molecules 767 adsorption and catalytic transformation.10 In general, it is extremely difficult to recover the used 768
nanomaterials from the environment. Consequently, the unrecovered graphene based nanomaterials 769
would be considered as new environmental pollutants. 770
Since size of the functional nanomaterials during application took main response for the 771
environmental residual problem after use. Preparation of macroscopic one (fibers), two (films) and three 772 (sponges) dimensional structures using graphene based materials158 is a potential way to relieve the 773
environmental impacts to some extent. GCM is a typical macroscopic structure prepared from graphene 774
based nanomaterials, which is an advanced separation tool for water reclamation. Obviously, most 775
properties of graphene and its derivatives were transferred into the macroscopic GCM membranes which 776
are much easier to be recovered or with lower risk to impact the application environment. However, the 777
amount of nanomaterial that would be released from GCM during application is another emerging 778
concern, which is directly related to the stability of graphene based nanomaterial in GCM. 779

In the case of SGM, a perfect graphene 2D sheet/film is with high mechanical strength.18 780 Nevertheless, the pore drilling process of SGM, which is usually high energy oxidative etching,23 may 781
generate graphene oxidation debris (OD). It has been reported that OD had similar structure but smaller 782
size (several nanometers) than GO, which was observed on the graphene surface after strong oxidation 783 process; in addition, OD could be removed from the graphene surface by base washing.159 It seems OD 784
could be released into the environment and cause environmental hazards when SGM was used. Thus, 785
additional cleaning procedure is suggested for SGM to remove OD after pore drilling before use. 786
The membrane stability is the main concern of MGMs. The only “glue” of MGM constructed from 787
graphene and its derivatives is the π-π interaction which would be partially counteracted by the 788
electrostatic repulsion because of the carboxylic groups on GO. Thus, it can be expected that not a small 789
amount of graphene based nanomaterial will be released from MGMs, especially for those construed 790
from pristine GO. Even reduction may eliminate electrostatic repulsion, the rGO MGM membrane is 791
still need further enhancement before practical applications. 792
To enhance the stability of laminated GCMs, the crosslinking agents were introduced into CGMs. 793
For example, positively charged macromolecules were assembled with GO nanosheets to fabricate 794
CGMs. However, more stable covalent bonds should be employed to bind graphene nanosheets in CGM 795
for further reducing or eliminating uncertainties and risks during environmental applications. 796
The stability of graphene based nanomaterial in PGM mainly depends on the interaction between the 797
nanosheets and the substrate membrane. Similarly, strong interaction such as covalent bond may not 798
only reduce the release amount of toxic graphene nanosheets but also maintain the surface modification 799
effect for a longer time. 800
In short, graphene nanosheets or nanoparticles are difficult to be recovered and may cause adverse 801
environmental impacts when they were dosed into the aquatic environment directly. As a typical 802

However, the stability of graphene based nanomaterials in GCM is the new emerging concern. The 804

808
5. Conclusions and Perspectives 809
Graphene-containing membranes (GCMs) showed desirable sustainability in two aspects. On one 810
hand, the membrane separation function was achieved by configuring graphene based nanomaterials in 811
different manners. At the same time, the shortcomings of membrane such as the selectivity/permeability 812
tradeoff and fouling were relieved to some extent in GCM whose performance and life-span were 813
improved because of extraordinary properties of graphene based nanomaterials. On the other hand, as 814
typical macroscopic structures, GCMs may reduce the environmental release of graphene based 815
nanomaterials during application, and thus, relieve the adverse impacts to the environment to some 816
extent. 817
In this review, the possible routes to construct single layered, multilayered and surface modified 818
GCMs were summarized. Subsequently, the sustainable applications of GCM, including advanced 819
separations such as isotope separation, gas separation, desalination, ion separation, nanofiltration, 820
ultrafiltration and pervaporation as well as beyond sieving functions such as conductive, antifouling, 821
adsorptive and photoactive membranes were discussed. The single layer graphene membrane (SGM) 822
indicated extraordinary permeability and selectivity in advanced separation processes because of the 823
atomic thickness. The interlayer space of laminated graphene membrane (MGM) is tunable confined 824
space showing extraordinary high water flux, which is considered as a perfect scalable replacement of 825

composite graphene membrane (CGM) property or induce additional function. Graphene and its 827
derivative are also fantastic materials for membrane surface modification, resulting improved 828
performance or extra function. 829
Even substantial progress has been made in the development and application of GCM, the 830
limitations and challenges of current GCMs are also obvious. The development of next-generation 831
GCMs should overcome major obstacles and target practical applications. Firstly, the fabrication of 832
large-area single-layer graphene sheet is of great interest in graphene-related fields, and it is also one of 833
the key steps in the development of scalable SGMs. Another key step is the experimental generation of 834
homogeneous subnanometer-sized pores on the graphene sheet. Recently, Geim’s group reported a 835
protocol to fabricate total carbon capillaries with precise size control at the atomic scale by using 836 graphene (one to ten layers) as the spacer.160 This work may shed some light on the generation of 837
subnanometer pores in SGMs. Secondly, the rapid water channels in multilayer GCMs are attractive, 838
and the channel size-tuning approaches need to be further improved. The functionalization of graphene 839
sheets to graphene derivatives also requires more efforts to quantitatively control the grafted functional 840
groups and the doped atoms on the lattice. On the other hand, stability is another concern with respect to 841
laminated GCMs. Otherwise, the high release amount of graphene from GCMs may cause new 842
environmental problems. Ideally, the next generation of multilayer GCMs should possess the same or a 843
similar separation performance as SGMs but be amenable to scaling up for practical applications. On the 844
application side, high-resolution separation of particles with similar sizes, such as isotopes, gas 845
molecules and ions, using GCMs should be further studied experimentally. As one of the most important 846
applications, high performance desalination requires the creation of future GCMs with high water 847
permeate flux and high salt rejection but low energy consumption and low fabrication cost. 848

In summary, graphene and graphene derivatives are excellent materials for membrane fabrication, 849
which have dramatically changed the concepts of conventional membrane with respect to both 850
preparation and application. The GCM membranes not only inherit the excellent properties of graphene 851
and its derivatives but also exhibit an enhanced separation performance, which sheds light on a potential 852
breakthrough in the trade-off between the permeability and selectivity of conventional membranes. Even 853
the production of GCM is still in laboratory scale, the further development and practical application of 854
GCMs may provide new solutions to global challenges such as the water crisis. 855
